loans.name: Saidu

texts.en: Saidu has been running his business for 4 years.  Married with 2 children, the 29-year-old father sells used shoes in the market of Makeni town in Sierra Leone.  With his previous loan from SMT, he was able to acquire a space for selling.  With a new market stall he would like to increase his stock and is requesting for a loan of $350.

loans.use: Saidu now has a space for his business, but needs more merchandise to sell for a profit.

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.en: Idrissa sells used shoes in the market town of Makeni in Sierra Leone. He would like to increase his stock with the latest models to attract more customers. Idrissa is therefore requesting another loan of $350 for this purpose.  Idrissa is 28 years old, married, and has 2 children.

loans.use: Idrissa wants his business to remain competetive and would use the loan to purchase shoes in all the latest styles that would satisfy customer demand.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Hawa has successfully accessed loans from SMT 7 times.  She sells rice, peppers, and pigeon peas.  Before the loans, Hawa had only 1 bag of rice as her stock, but now she can purchase up to 8 bags and has diversified her business.  She is now confident she can expand the business and is requesting a loan of $1200.  The 48-year-old widow will be able to earn more income to educate her 5 children.

loans.use: Hawa is well on her way to achieving a sustainable business.  She has invested all her loans wisely in her business, and has managed it well.  She needs another larger loan to continue with her planned expansion.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel sells soft drinks in the town of Makeni in Sierra Leone.  His stock increased after accessing several small loans from SMT.  Samuel has saved some money from the profit and is requesting a Loan of $350. to purchase re-conditioned used refrigerators for the business.  Samuel is married, 38 years old, and has 2 children.

loans.use: Samuel wants to meet the summer time demand for cold drinks.  He needs the loan to purchase used refrigerators for his business.

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.en: Rosaline sells rice and palm oil in the market of Makeni in Sierra Leone.  Before the loan, she had two bags of rice and 20 gallons of palm oil as her stock. With the loans she increased her stock to 5 bags of rice and 20 gallons of palm oil and was able to pay her loan installments on time.  36-year-old Rosaline would like to increase her stock and income, and is therefore requesting a loan of $525. She is married with 3 children.

loans.use: Rosaline needs a loan to increase her stock of food items so that she can generate additional profits.

loans.name: Fatu

texts.en: Fatu is 35 years old and married with 2 children.  She sells locally grown rice and palm oil to retailers in the market of Makeni.  Her capital is insufficient to provide enough products to meet her customer demand. This has forced her to make several trips to purchase supplies, which is time-consuming and expensive.  She is therefore requesting a loan of $525. to increase her capital and expand her business.

loans.use: Fatu needs to buy more of her supplies on wholesale to cut down on time and money spent traveling to acquire them.

loans.name: Kadi

texts.en: Kadi produces and sells tie dye materials in the town of Makeni.  She has had her business for 4 years with loans from SMT.  Kadi’s product is known as one of the best tie dye materials in Sierra Leone and it has high demand in the neighboring cities. Kadi has a plan to increase her production to meet her customer demands.  She is therefore requesting a loan of $1,050.

loans.use: Kadi would like to be able to better meet her customers demand by increasing her productivity.  Additional business capital is necessary for her to meet her goal.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa T. is 29 years old and married with 2 children.  He sells drinks in Makeni town. Musa has been running the business for 3 years and his business has expanded as a result of the previous loans.  He is requesting more loans to expand the stock.

loans.use: Musa wants to use the loan to add additional variety of drinks to his drink shop to hopefully attract new customers.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John has been running his business for 21 years on a small scale.  With his last loan, he purchased one sewing machine and some sewing materials to expand the business.  He also employed one tailor to assist with the sewing of men’s clothing.  He would like to expand his business and is therefore requesting for a loan of $350. for that purpose.

loans.use: John has had great success with his business since his last loan with SMT, and he hopes Kiva will help him continue to increase his production of men's clothing.

loans.name: Yawa

texts.fr:
Yawa N. is married and the mother of four children, all of whom are in school. She has been the owner of a restaurant called Tantine de Fufu (Fufu Aunty) for 10 years. (Fufu is a local dish.) The restaurant is located downtown and welcomes many low-income customers. With the income from it, she covers over 80% of family expenses because of her husband's paltry and unsteady income. She is on her second loan, which is something she has always repaid. With the present loan, she is thinking of improving her restaurant's accommodations to meet customer needs and to increase her income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Yawa N., mariée et mère de 04 enfants tous à l’école est propriétaire d’un restaurant Dénommé tantiD De fufu (Plat local) depuis 10 ans. Ce restaurant est situé au centre ville et accueille de nombreux clients à faibles revenus. Avec le revenu elle participe à plus de 80% des charges familiales du fait des revenus dérisoires et réguliers de son mari. Madame Yawa est à son deuxième crédit qu’elle a toujours payé .Avec le présent crédit elle pense améliorer la capacité d’accueil de son restaurant afin de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle et d’augmenter son revenu

loans.use: Fix up her restaurant's decor

loans.name: Enyonam

texts.fr:
Enyonam K. (the woman standing and dressed in a print boubou) is 28 years old, married, and is the mother of three. She has been the owner of a hair salon named Enyonam for five years. She manages her salon with professionalism and is thinking of bolstering her salon by acquiring a hair dryer. She is also thinking of creating a more welcoming environment by buying armchairs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Enyonam K. (femme débout et habillée en boubou de tissu imprimé), âgée de 28 ans, mariée et mère de 03 enfants est propriétaire d’un salon de coiffure dénommée coiffure Enyonam) depuis 05 ans. Elle gère son salon avec professionnalisme et pense renforcer la capacité de son salon par l’acquisition d’un séchoir et améliorer le cadre d’accueil par l’achat des fauteuils.

loans.use: To acquire a hair dryer and to upgrade her hair salon

loans.name: Estela Del Carmen

texts.es:
Estela is 31 years old and owns a convenience store, located in the popular market Ivan Montenegro, where she sells milk, pasta, meat, dairy products, pulses, tuna, canned goods, and personal items, among others multiple products of different brands and prices. This business has allowed her to improve the quality of life of her family and her two children. She works every day, and currently demand for her products is high, since most of the people from Nicaragua buy from different markets due to the accessibility of the prices. She wants to expand her business and sell her products wholesale, and that is why she would like to obtain a loan to buy different products that will allow her to increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

Estela tiene 31 años de edad, cuenta con una venta de abarrotaría ubicada en el populoso mercado Iván Montenegro en la cual vende granos básicos, leche, pastas alimenticias, carnes, lácteos, atunes, sardinas, enlatados de frutas, productos de higiene personal entre otros productos, cuenta con un surtido inventario de productos de diferentes marcas, precios y presentaciones. El negocio le ha permitido mejorar el nivel de vida de su familia, tiene 2 hijos los cuales ha podido sacar adelante, atiende todos los días de la semana, en estos momentos el negocio posee una buena demanda de productos, ya que la mayoría de la población nicaragüense compra sus alimentos en los diferentes mercados, debido a lo accesibles que son los precios. La señora esta en aras de expandirse y ofrecer sus productos al por mayor, es por eso que desea un préstamo para iniciar la compra de alimentos varios que le permitan aumentar su ganancias.

loans.use: To buy products such as meat, dairy products, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edita A. is a 36-year-old woman who is married to Emilio Gonzalez. Together, they have five children, most of whom are in high school. The husband and wife pair work together in their small business selling various goods.

Now they want to invest in a new variety of goods, including tennis shoes, fans, blankets, and sheets. They are hoping to buy a vehicle that will help them to expand their clientele and to look in other places for goods.

loans.use: To buy tennis shoes, pants, fans, blankets, and sheets.

loans.name: Grace

texts.fr:
Grâce T. (the woman seated with a comb in hand) is 25 years old, married, and the mother of one child. She has been the owner of a hair salon named Grace for three years. She professionally manages her salon and is thinking of bolstering her salon by acquiring two hair dryers. She is also thinking of creating a more welcoming environment by buying an electric fan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Grâce T. (femme assise avec peigne en main), âgée de 25 ans, mariée et mère de 01 enfant est propriétaire d’un salon de coiffure dénommée coiffure la Grâce) depuis 03 ans. Elle gère son salon avec professionnalisme et pense renforcer la capacité de son salon par l’acquisition de deux séchoirs et améliorer le cadre d’accueil par l’achat d’un ventilateur.

loans.use: To buy two hair dryers and an electric fan

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando G. is 62 years old and has been married for 30 years. He and his wife have seven children, some of whom are in the university and some of whom live with them and help with their business.

Since 1986, Fernando has run a small convenience store from his house, which he began with a small amount of capital.

His dream is to see all of his children finish their schooling at the university level, so that they may have greater access to professions. He does not want them to struggle as he and his wife have had to. With the loan, Fernando will buy products to sell, including oils, flour, sugar, pasta, and fruits and vegetables. These goods will help his business grow and flourish.

loans.use: To buy oil, flour, sugar, pasta, yerba mate (tea), fruits and vegetable, mayonnaise, canned goods, and refreshments.

loans.name: Hugo

texts.en:
Hugo A. is a father of one who works very hard to provide for his son and wife. He is a motorcycle mechanic and has been one since he was very young. His father was in the same line of work and taught the profession to his son. Hugo’s hope is that his son will continue with his education and go on to the university.

Hugo is asking for a loan today to buy more parts for his service shop. He will buy starters, crowns, pistons and chains, and this will help him meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: To buy parts to fix motorcycles.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Elegantes, Group 1

texts.en:
Benise M. lives in a small community outside of Puerto Plata on the northern coast of the Dominican Republic. She is originally from Haiti. Her parents came to the Dominican Republic in hopes of finding more opportunities and a better life. Benise is 29 years old and lives with her husband and her child.

Benise has worked hard for many years but has only made enough money to barely provide for her needs. She lives in a Haitian community where unemployment rates and poverty are seen in large percentages. Currently, she sells food to about 40 construction workers a day by walking around and looking for current building projects. Work is very hard for her because she walks around all day and already has problems with one of her knees.

She currently lives with a large group of family members but one day hopes to build her own house. In five years, she hopes to build a home of her own. Benise feels that it is very hard to live in a country and a house that is not her own. She is very appreciative of the opportunity that she is now getting and desperately wants to improve her life. She hopes to give her son a better life and the chance to attend a good school.

On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and from Benise herself, we thank you for your support with this microloan!

loans.use: to purchase food staples

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria Céspedes has been married for 18 years to her husband, who repairs car radiators. Together, they have two children who are in high school.

Her husband's income helped Maria to open her own small business eight years ago. She sells beauty products, like shampoo, conditioner, perfumes, and facial creams. She began as a traveling saleswoman, but now has her own place in a nearby market. Maria began working with her children’s education in mind.

Maria will use the loan to invest in new products. More variety will make for a better income, because her store will be more competitive.

loans.use: To buy perfume, face creams, hydrating soaps, shampoo, and conditioner

loans.name: Maximo

texts.en:
Maximo M. has been happily married for 23 years to his wife, Bernarda Maldonado. Together they have two children, who are both in high school. Maximo works as a carpenter and his whole family is involved in the business.

He was employed in a private construction business but, in 1995, he decided to start his own carpentry business. Now he makes furniture that he sells in his city and the surrounding towns.

He is asking for a loan today to help his family’s business grow. With the money, he will buy wood, nails, polishes, and other necessary materials.

loans.use: To buy wood, nails, and other construction material.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Elegantes, Group 2

texts.en:
Edlina is a young woman who lives with her husband in small community in Puerto Plata. They are both originally from Haiti but have come to the Dominican Republic to find better work and a more prosperous life.

Edlina travels once a week to Santiago, a city about an hour away, to purchase clothing and other miscellaneous items. She sells these items in her community, either from her home or by walking up and down the streets showing people her merchandise. It has been very hard for her to make enough profit to pay for the bus rides and to cover other business expenses. Currently, she and her husband are renting a small house but her biggest dream is to one day have a home of her own.

She wants to thank everyone who is supporting her loan and has taken the time to read about her life and business. On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and on behalf of Edlina, we thank you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase clothing and miscellaneous accessories

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Elegantes , Group 3

texts.en:
Ystella is a vivacious 32 year old woman who lives in a small Haitian community on the northern coast of Puerto Plata. She lives with her husband and five children (ages 12, 9, 6, 3, 1) in a small, one bedroom house.

Ystella currently sells a variety of items to the people living in her community. She walks around everyday trying to find people to purchase the items that she has on hand. Currently, her biggest problem are customers who buy on credit and never pay her back. With this loan, she hopes to set up a store that her customers can come to and carry a larger inventory of household items. Her husband works in construction and is often out of work for weeks at a time. Having two incomes will greatly benefit their family. Eventually, Ystella would love to be able to build her own home for her family.

On behalf of Ystella, and everyone here at Esperanza International, we sincerely thank you for your support!

loans.use: to buy materials to set up a shop and buy inventory of household goods

loans.name: Salustiano

texts.en:
Salustino G. has a wife and two young children. He works as a mechanic and is in the business of selling car parts to support his small family. He began the business a while back with a friend, but now runs it solo.

He is asking for a loan today to buy some merchandise for his shop. These include belts, lubricants, truck batteries, seat covers, and engine parts. With these goods, he will be able to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: To buy batteries, lubricants, belts, and other car maintenance supplies.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Elegantes, Group 4

texts.en:
Antoinne is a 40 year old Haitian woman who lives in a small village on the northern coaS.of the Dominican Republic. She moved to the Dominican Republic about 10 years ago and left her two oldeS.children in Haiti. She had to leave all of her things in Haiti when she left. Her 25 year old son lives in the Dominican Republic now and she is able to see him frequently.

Antoinne currently sells second-hand clothing from her home, at the markets, and by walking along the streets. It is a struggle for her to pay rent every month. She hopes to use this loan in order to expand her inventory and increase her profit margin. Right now she is focusing on covering basic expenses but in the future she wants to buy her own home.

On behalf of Antoinne, and everyone here at Esperanza International, we sincerely thank you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase new and nicer clothing to expand inventory

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Elegantes , Group 5

texts.en:
Adinord is a beautiful young 22 year old single mom with a one year old boy. Adinord’s parents died when she was a child and she grew up as an orphan in her native country of Haiti. She has never had anyone to take care of her and it has been very hard.

She currently sells dishes and other household items from her house and in the nearby market. Her two main goals are to expand her business and buy her own house either in the Dominican Republic or Haiti. She plans on using this loan to buy more merchandise for her small business so that she can raise her son and give him a good life.

On behalf of Adinord, and everyone here at Esperanza International, we sincerely thank you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase dishes and other household items

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria Bogarin is 40-year-old mother of tour. Her two eldest are in the university and the other two are still in high school. In 1994, Victoria began a small convenience store with capital her husband gave her. He grows and sells animals, like pigs and chickens.

Victoria is asking for a loan to buy more products for her store. She will invest in fruits and vegetables, sugar, oil, and soft drinks. She needs to continue working to save enough money to help her two younger children enter college.

loans.use: To buy sugar, oil, flour, fruits and vegetables, general groceries for her convenience store.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio is happily married to his wife Ana Caceres. Together they have a small daughter and a rotisserie business. For years, Antonio worked as a chef for a private restaurant however, after saving, he was able to become independent and open his own restaurant.

Now his restaurant is a success and his great dream is to open branches of his restaurant in different cities throughout the country. The loan he is asking for is to purchase a new oven to bake and roast his chickens. This will allow him to produce more quantity and gain greater revenues.

loans.use: To buy an oven to bake chicken.

loans.name: Mujeres Solidarias Group

texts.en:
Deliana is a 22 year old woman who lives with her husband and three children (ages: 5, 4, 2) in the small community of Cangrejo, which is on the northern coast of the Dominican Republic. This is the first loan she has applied for through Kiva and she is really excited to expand her current business. Over the past couple of years she has been selling different types of homemade food to the people in her community. With this loan she wants to set up a storefront by her home and expand the variety of food she is able to make every day.

When she is not working she loves talking with her friends and catching up with her neighbors.

She wants to thank everyone who is supporting her loan and has taken the time to read about her life and business. On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and on behalf of Deliana, we thank you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase materials to build a store; expand inventory of food staples, fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Vidal

texts.es:
Mr. Vidal Benítez i 53 years old and has been happily married for 26 years with Mrs. Epifania Balbuena who is 48 years old. The marriage has three children, the youngest of which is 19 years old and continues to live with his parents; he is attending his second year of Information Engineering.

As of 20 years ago, Mr. Vidal Benítez has been in charge of a clothing store that is strategically located on a main avenue of the city he resides in. His wife helps him out with this business. It is worth mentioning that thanks to the personalized attention that they give to their clients, and due to the great variety of products, they now have loyal customers. The client asks for a loan to buy pants, shirts, T-shirts, shorts, athletic apparel (athletic shoes), shoes, belts, bouses, jerseys and purses. The loan will also go towards expanding his business even more and offer a greater variety and quality of products to his customers

.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

El Señor Vidal Benítez de 53 años de edad esta felizmente casado desde hace 26 años con la señora Epifania Balbuena de 48 años, el matrimonio tiene tres hijos. De los cuales el menor de ellos, de 19 años de edad sigue viviendo con sus padres y está cursando el 2º año de la carrera Ingeniería Informática.

Desde hace 20 años el Señor Vidal Benítez se encuentra al mando de una ropería que esta estratégicamente ubicado sobre la avenida principal de la ciudad donde reside, en dicho negocio recibe la ayuda de su esposa. Cabe mencionar que gracias a la atención personalizada que ellos le otorgan a sus clientes y por la gran variedad de productos, ya cuentan con su fiel clientela. El cliente solicita el préstamo para la compra de pantalones, camisas, remeras, shorts, championes (calzados deportivos), zapatos, cintos, blusas, kepis y bolsones. Para ampliar aún más su negocio y ofrecer mayor variedad y calidad de productos a sus clientes.

loans.use: To purchase pants, shirts, T-shirts, shorts, athletic apparel (athletic shoes), shoes, belts, bouses, jerseys and purses.

loans.name: Evenecer En Cristo Group

texts.en:
Dilia J. is a gracious 35 year old woman who lives in Pancho Mateo, a small community in Puerto Plata. Pancho Mateo is one of the poorest communities in Puerto Plata – it is typical to see cardboard nailed to thin metal sheets serving as houses and the use of thin cloth as doors. In midst of poverty, the people remain full of joy and truly love the people they live with. Dilia and her husband raise two children and life has been very hard for them.

Dilia has chronic stomach problems and experiences severe pain but she can’t afford to buy the proper medicine. She currently has her own business selling clothes, shoes, soap, and lotion. Her goals for the future are to have a proper house with a good roof and floor and to have a larger business that makes more money. She wants to continue sending her children to school and she would also like to buy medicine for herself.

loans.use: to purchase apparel and personal care products

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Por El Progresso, Group 1

texts.en:
Constancia is an ambitious woman with a great sense of humor and vibrant personality. She lives in La Viara, a small village in Puerto Plata, with her husband and two children. You would never know she is 42 years old since she active, energetic, and young-spirited. When she is not working she enjoys spending time with her family and watching television. Although rice and beans are the typical Dominican food, she informed us that vegetables were her favorite food and they help keep her healthy.

Constancia sells clothing from her house and also has a large clientele that comes to her home for manicures. This is her second loan and she wants to use it to purchase a larger inventory of clothing and some new supplies for her manicure business. A lot of her materials are worn and she needs to replace them in order to do continue doing nails.

On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and from Constancia herself, we thank you for your support with this business loan!

loans.use: to purchase clothing and personal care products

loans.name: San Juanita Maricela

texts.es:
This business is my family's source of income and both my husband and my job. When he visits clients, I am in charge of the business. However, we are lacking raw material and a machine to make steel figures. We ask for a loan of $1,200 USD to buy raw material and a machine to solder steel.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de la familia en trabajos mi esposo y yo. Cuando el anda visitando los clientes yo me encargo del negocio pero nos esta haciendo falta materia prima y una maquina para ser las figuras de acero. Solicitamos un préstamo de $1,200.00 Dlls. para la comprar de materia prima y una maquina para soldar acero.

loans.use: Purchase raw material and a machine to solder steel.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Por El Progress, Group 2

texts.en:
Dilcia is a young and vivacious woman who lives with her husband and three children (ages: 11, 6, 5) in a small community in Puerto Plata. She works a lot, but when she is not working she loves watching tv and drinking soda. This is her second loan. With her first loan she set up a small juice stand in her community. She sells several different types of juice including passion fruit, orange, pineapple, and apple.

Dilcia's first loan allowed her to make about $2000 RD Pesos (about $60 USD) more every month than she did before. She hopes to continue improving her juice stand and also wants to carry a larger variety of juices. She will buy a blender to make the polular “baditas” drinks that combine fruit, ice, and milk.

She wants to thank everyone who is supporting her loan, and who has taken the time to read about her life and her business. On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and on behalf of Dilcia, we thank you for your support!

loans.use: tp purchase a blender, milk, ice and fruit

loans.name: Ramiro

texts.es:
I have a junk yard with cars that can no longer be fixed. I sell the parts that are still in good condition. This business is my family's source of income. I lack parts pertaining to more recent car models. I ask for a loan of $800 USD to buy more car parts.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo un yonque de carro que ya no tienes compostura y les vendo las piezas que están en buenas condiciones. Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de mi familia. En el negocio me esta haciendo falta mas piezas de carros de modelos mas recientes. Solicito un préstamo de $800.00 Dlls para la comprar de piezas de carros.

loans.use: Purchase car parts

loans.name: Martha's Group

texts.en:
This committee of women has been formed for four months. It still is composed mostly of the first members. but some new women who have come on board. All of the women work in their own businesses. Many sell fruits, like oranges, pineapples, mangos, and lemons. Some make clothing, and others have their own small convenience stores, where they sell a little bit of everything.

These women are asking for a loan together so that they will have the support, both financially and socially. All of the women are working to insure that their children attend school.

loans.use: To buy the ingredients to make Paraguayan delicacies. Other women will use the funds to buy fruits, cosmetics, crafting, sewing material and refreshments.

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es:
A few years ago, Jorge became unemployed after working as a workman in the 'franca' zone. Having to feed two kids, he decided to start doing something well-paid so that he could pay the household costs, so 9 months ago he started to sell small bags of bread, sweet bread and toasted bread to grocery stores, all-purpose stores and certain houses. Every morning he buys bread in the main market, and then goes to sell it to his clients that rely on him. His wife supports him by selling soft drinks from home, all so that they can make it through and give their kids a good life. He requires a loan to buy a motor to fit it to his bike, as this is the mode of transport he uses to sell the bread.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Jorge hace algunos años quedó sin empleo, trabajaba de operario en una zona franca. Teniendo que alimentar a sus 2 hijos, opta por emprender una actividad que le fuera rentable y con la cual pudiera pagar los gastos del hogar y es desde hace 9 meses que se ha dedicado a distribuir bolsas de pan simple, pan dulce y pan tostado a pulperías, misceláneas y casas particulares. Todas las mañanas compra el pan en el mercado mayoreo y posteriormente sale a venderlo a sus clientes fijos con los que cuenta Jorge. Su esposa lo apoya vendiendo refrescos en su vivienda, todo con el propósito de salir adelante y poder darles una vida cómoda a sus hijos. Requiere del préstamo para comprar un motor para instalarlo en su bicicleta que es su medio de transporte para vender el pan.

loans.use: To buy a motor to fit it to his bike / Comprar Motor para instalárselo a su bicicleta

loans.name: Alma Bedelia

texts.es:
I have a business that sells used and new clothing. I set up shop outside my home, which allows me to also take care of my family. My store needs new merchandise and a wider variety of items; I would also like to sell shoes. I ask for a loan of $700 USD to purchase new merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo un negocio de venta de ropa usada y nueva. El negocio lo tengo fuera de mi casa y así atiendo a mi familia. En el negocio me esta haciendo falta mas mercancía nueva y variedad de artículos, también me gustaría vender calzado. Solicito un préstamo de $700.00 Dlls para la compra de mercancía nueva.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
Luz Marina participates in community service and lives in the township of Laureles Sur. Her husband is a construction worker and works for himself. The family has been affected by the economic recession the country finds itself in at the moment. Mrs. Luz helps her husband with all the expenses and is selling used clothing at her house. Her clients are the people that live in the area who have limited resources, thereby making this kind of business an excellent option. By night, Mrs. Luz works as a volunteer doing community service. She contributes to the social development of the community and helps at risk teens to deal with society. Her business has allowed her to better her humble lifestyle. At the moment, Mrs. Luz needs to build a wall at her house; she asks for a loan to buy construction materials since her husband will build it himself. These plans will help her develop her business and take it to a higher level.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Luz Marina realiza labores sociales en su comunidad, habita en el asentamiento Laureles Sur, su esposo se desempeña como albañil, trabaja por cuenta propia. En estos momentos el país se encuentra en una resección económica, por lo cual esta familia se han visto afectada. Doña Luz apoya a su esposo con todos los gastos y está vendiendo ropa usada en su casa de habitación, sus clientes son los pobladores de su zona, los cuales son de escasos recursos económicos y por lo tanto es una excelente opción este tipo de negocio. Por la noche la señora se dedica a trabajar de manera voluntaria en labores sociales, en donde contribuye al desarrollo social de la comunidad y a formar jóvenes en riesgos encaminados a enfrentarse a la sociedad. Su negocio le ha permitido mejorar su humilde vivienda, en estos momentos doña Luz necesita iniciar a levantar el muro de su vivienda, por el cual solicita un préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción, ya que su mismo esposo es quien realizarà la construcción, ya que los planes que cuenta esta señora es la de desarrollar su negocio a un mejor nivel.

loans.use: Buy construction materials to build a wall at her home

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start a business

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Por El Progresso, Group 3

texts.en:
Santa is a 26 year old young woman who lives with her husband and one year old daughter in the community of La Viara. She is currently attending a local university and spends most of her time studying when she is not at work or caring for her daughter.

Santa runs a small business selling silver, shoes, and other accessories. She has only been able to carry a small inventory due to a lack of sufficient capital. Now, she hopes to increase her profits. She spends most of her money on school and helping her husband support the household. Her goal is to one day have her own boutique of specialty merchandise and to have a college degree.

On behalf of Santa, and everyone here at Esperanza International, we sincerely thank you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase jewelry, womens' shoes and other accessories

loans.name: Santos Carmela

texts.es:
Mrs. Santos Carmela A. C. is 46 years old, she has two children, but only one still requires her care. She lives in the small town of Cuyuchugo in the district of Usquil, Otuzco province, La Libertad department in Peru.

Mrs. Santos only studied until 9th grade of school. In her study center, in the class of "Education for the Job", she was taught how to make simple clothing, and since then she has practiced what she learned, making aprons, dresses, skirts, and other articles of clothing. For some time she traveled through different settlements to offer her creations. Her sales were good and with the profits she set up a small general store.

She started buying basic need products, and little by little she expanded her business. Mrs. Santos is part of the communal bank, "San Juan de Miraflores", where she received her first loan for S/. 300.00, with which she bought cloth, thread, and zippers for her creations.

With the loan for S/. 2500.00, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will travel to Trujillo to buy a sack of rice, sugar, a box of oil, tuna, pasta, and sweets.

Mrs. Santos' dream is to have a business in a central place in Otuzco.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Santos Carmela A. C. tiene 46 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos pero sólo uno aún necesita de su cuidado. Vive en el Poblado Menor de Cuyuchugo del Distrito de Usquil de la Provincia de Otuzco del Departamento de La Libertad – Perú. La señora Santos estudió sólo hasta el tercer año de secundaria. En su centro de estudios, en el curso de Educación para el Trabajo, le enseñaron a confeccionar ropa sencilla desde entonces puso en práctica lo que había aprendido, cocía mandiles, vestidos, faldas y otras prendas; después de un tiempo viajó por diferentes caseríos a ofrecer sus confecciones, las ventas le fueron bien y con las utilidades que obtuvo acondicionó una pequeña bodega. Empezó comprando productos de primera necesidad y poco a poco está ampliando su negocio. La señora Santos forma parte del Banco Comunal “San Juan de Miraflores” lugar en el que le dieron un primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 , con el que compró telas, hilos y cierres para sus confecciones. Con el préstamo de S/. 2500.00 que cancelará en 4 meses viajará a Trujillo para comprar un saco de arroz, azúcar, una caja de aceite, atún, fideos y golosinas. El sueño de la señora Santos es poner un negocio en un lugar céntrico en Otuzco

loans.use: Buying sacks of rice, sugar, and other products for her general store (Con el prestamo comprara sacos de arroz, azucar y otros productos para su bodega)

loans.name: Fabiola Marleni

texts.es:
Mrs. Fabiola Marleni R. V. is 32 years old, and she finished elementary school. She has 5 children who still depend on her. She lives downtown in the small town of Simon Bolivar, which belongs to the district of Mache, Otuzco province, La Libertad department in Peru.

She works buying and selling small animals such as: pigs, chickens and guinea pigs. She travels through the district of Julcan to buy these animals, fattens them for some time, and sells them for a profit. She offers them to different restaurants in the districts of Mache and Agallpampa.

Her business started with a few small animals, and with the profits she made, she little by little started buying sweets and general store products to set up a small store in her home. After a shot time, she had to close this business because her children ate the sweets and she had nothing to sell; she decided to sell only animals.

With the first loan she received from her communal bank, "Mujeres con Future" (women with future) for S/. 300.00, she was able to increase the quantity of animals to offer for sale, buying piglets and chickens.

With the loan for S/. 800.00, which she will pay in 4 months, she will buy 6 sheep which she will kill at the slaughterhouse to sell their meat.

Mrs. Fabiola is a member of a mothers club in her area called "Corazon de Jesus" (Jesus' heart). Her greatest dream is to open her general store again, to be able to have another source of income to cover the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Fabiola Marleni Rodríguez V. tiene 32 años de edad, con grado de instrucción primaria completa. Tiene 5 hijos que aun dependen de ella. Vive en el centro poblado menor de Simón Bolívar perteneciente al distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco departamento La Libertad - Perú

Se dedica a la compra y venta de animales menores tales como: huachos, gallinas, chanchos y cuyes. Viaja al distrito de Julcán para comprar éstos animales, por un tiempo los engorda para venderlos a mayor precio, los ofrece por diferentes restaurantes de los distritos de Mache y Agallpampa.

Su negocio se inició con pocos animales menores, con la ganancia que obtenía poco a poco fue comprando golosinas y abarrotes para acondicionar una pequeña tienda en su casa, al poco tiempo cerro ese negocio debido a que sus niños consumían las golosinas y ya no tenia que vender; decidió vender sólo animales.

Con el primer préstamo que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres con Futuro”de S/. 300.00 pudo incrementar la cantidad de animales para vender, compro chanchos pequeños y gallinas.

Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00 el cual pagara en 4 meses ,comprará 6 carneros que matará en el camal para distribuir la carne.

La señora Fabiola es socia del club de madres de su sector llamado “Corazón de Jesús”. Su mayor sueño es aperturar nuevamente su bodega, de esa manera tener otro ingreso para ayudar a cubrir los gastos del hogar.

loans.use: Buying animals to sell them later

loans.name: Hermelinda Epifania

texts.es:
Mrs. Hermelinda Epifania V. D. Castillo is 54 years old and studied until 8th graD. of school. She has four children but none of them depend on her. She lives in the Quiñigon Ave. in the district of Mache, Otuzco province, La Libertad department in Peru.

Since she has lived with her husband, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle and breeding small animals such as: pigs, chickens, and guinea pigs. She walks through the farms and several settlements to buy cattle at the lowest price to be able to increase her profits. She currently has two cows, two calves, and some pigs which she will fatten for some time to later sell them.

She became part of the communal bank, "Women of Mache" in which she received a loan for S/. 300.00 and with this money she bought two lambs.

With the loan for S/.2500.00, which she will pay in 4 months, she will buy 2 cows.

Mrs. Hermelinda is treasurer for the popular diner in her community called "Virgen D. la Puerta". She has planned to save capital to open a store in her home, because she is afraid that because of her age, in the future she will not be able to work buying and selling animals.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Hermelinda Epifanía V. D. Castillo tiene 54 años D. edad, estudió hasta el segundo año D. secundaria .Tiene cuatro hijos pero ninguno depenD. D. ella. Vive en la Av. Quiñigón del distrito D. Mache provincia D. Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad - Perú

DesD. que convive con su esposo se dedica al negocio D. la compra y venta D. reses y a la crianza D. animales menores tales como: cerdos, gallinas y cuyes. Camina por las chacras y por los diversos caseríos a conseguir ganado a menor precio y así poder obtener mayores utilidades. Actualmente tiene 2 vacas, 2 terneros y algunos huachos que los engordarán por un tiempo para venderlos después.

Ella integra el Banco Comunal “Mujeres D. Mache” en el cual recibió su primer préstamo D. S/. 300.00 con este dinero compró 2 corderos.

Con el préstamo D. S/. 2500.00 el cual pagará en 4 cuatro meses comprará 2 vacas.

La señora Hermelinda es tesorera del comedor popular D. su comunidad llamado”Virgen D. la Puerta”. Se ha proyectado ahorrar y tener un capital para abrir una tienda en su casa, debido a que tiene temor que por su edad más adelante ya no pueda dedicarse a la compra y venta D. animales.

loans.use: Buying animals to sell (Con el prestamo comprara animales para su venta)

loans.name: Justa Sabina

texts.es:
Mrs. Justa S. C. is 54 years old. She studied until 3rd grade of elementary school. She has two children who are grown up and do not depend on her. She lives in the district of Mache, Otuzco province, La Libertad department in Peru.

The business she has is the sale of meat from pigs, piglets, and beef, which she kills after some time of having bought them and she distributes the meat to restaurants in the districts of Julcan and Trujillo.

Previously, she worked only to farming, planting potatoes, but she had to stop this activity because the price of potatoes is low and it was not profitable; for some time she lost the capital invested in her farm, because aside from the problem of low prices, there was a pest that attacked farms. This is why she decided to work in her current business.

She became part of the communal bank, "Women of Mache" in which she received a loan for S/. 300.00 and with this money she bought two pigs.

With the loan for S/.800.00, which she will pay in 4 months, she will buy 3 pigs and 4 sheep. Mrs. Justa dreams of setting up a general store in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Justa Sánchez C. tiene 54 años de edad, estudió hasta el tercer grado de primaria. Tiene dos hijos que ya son mayores y ya no dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad - Perú

El negocio que tiene es la venta de carne de cerdo, huachos y reses el cual los mata después de cierto tiempo de haberlos comprado y lo distribuye por los restaurantes de los distritos de Julcán y Trujillo.

Anteriormente solo se dedicaba a la chacra, sembraba papas pero tuvo que dejar esa actividad porque el precio de la papa es bajo y ya no le convenía; por una época perdió el capital invertido en estas siembras ya que aparte de ese problema hubo una plaga que atacó a las plantaciones. Por eso decide dedicarse a su actual negocio.

Ella integra el Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Mache” en el cual le dieron un préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compró dos chanchos.

Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00 que pagará en 4 meses comprará 3 cerdos y 4 carneros. La señora Justa sueña con poner una tienda de abarrotes en su domicilio.

loans.use: Buying more animals for her business.

loans.name: Nery Soledad

texts.es:
Mrs. Nery Soledad V. Castro is 33 years old. She studied until 3rd grade of elementary school. She lives in the district of Mache, Otuzco province in the La Libertad department in Peru. She has five children who still depend on her.

She works buying and selling smaller animals and cheese. She travels through the districts of Julcan and Usquil to buy and sell her products.

She started her business when she received some cows as inheritance from her parents. She would take advantage of the milk of these animals to produce cheese and cuajada (milk curd). Later, she found herself in the necessity of selling her cattle, and since then she would buy milk to continue with the cheese production. However, she realized that it was cheaper to buy the milk curd already made. Currently she buys 20 to 30 kg of milk curd, which she uses in part to prepare cheese and in part to sell directly.

Through a very close friend, she became part of the communal bank "Women with Future" in which she received her first loan for S/. 300.00 and with this money she bought chickens, guinea pigs, and small pigs.

With the loan for S/.1000.00, which she will pay in 4 moths, she will buy two young pigs and some milk curd. Mrs. Nelly's dream is to buy a computer so that her children can do school work.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Nery Soledad V. Castro tiene 33 años de edad, estudió hasta el tercer grado de primaria. Vive en el distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad – Perú. Tiene cinco hijos que aun dependen de ella.

Se dedica a la compra y venta de animales menores y quesillo, viaja por los distritos de Julcán y Usquil para comprar y vender sus productos.

Su negocio se inicia cuando recibió algunas vacas como herencia de sus padres, aprovechaba la leche de estos animales para elaborar quesos y cuajada (quesillo), posteriormente tuvo la necesidad de vender su ganado, desde entonces compraba leche para seguir con la elaboración pero se dio cuenta que le salía mas a cuenta comprar el quesillo ya hecho. Actualmente compra de 20 a 30 kilogramos de quesillo de los cuales una parte lo usa para preparar queso y la otra lo vende directamente.

Por intermedio de una amiga muy cercana se pudo integrar al Banco Comunal “Mujeres con Futuro” en el que recibió su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compró gallinas, cuyes y chanchos pequeños.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1000.00 que cancelará en cuatro meses comprará 2 huachos y quesillo. El sueño de la señora Nery es comprar una computadora para que sus hijos puedan hacer sus tareas del colegio.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy 2 young pigs and milk curd

loans.name: Carmen Maribel

texts.es:
Mrs. Carmen Maribel E. Rodríguez is 24 years old and studied only through elementary school. She has two children who still depend on her. She lives in the small population center of Campo Bello in the Mache district of Otuzco Province in the city of La Libertad, Peru.

She began her business very young selling bread and “turrones” (nougat candies) to the different residents who came through her area. She set up shop on a corner and sold her goods from a basket. With her earnings she was eventually able to purchase a candy case in order to exhibit her sweets. Over time she had the good idea of creating a small store in her house, and she began to purchase soft drinks and snacks.

Through a family member she was able to join the Communal Bank “Mujeres con Futuro” (Women with a future). From this group she obtained her first loan of S/.300.00 (approximately $100 U.S.) with which she purchased several boxes of soft drinks.

The loan she is seeking is also for S/. 300.00 ($100 U.S.) to be paid back in four months. With this loan Carmen will purchase two boxes of beer, some snacks, and some candies.

Carmen’s dream is to have a larger business. There is demand in her area since it is a place that many people have to pass through on their way to Julcán and Mache.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Carmen Maribel E. Rodríguez tiene 24 años de edad, estudió solo primaria completa. Tiene dos hijos que aun dependen de ella. Vive en el centro poblado menor Campo Bello distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco en el Departamento La Libertad - Perú Desde que era joven inicio su negocio vendiendo pan y turrones a los diferentes pobladores que llegaban por la zona, se ubicaba en una esquina para ofrecer sus productos en una canasta, poco a poco con sus ganancias compró un mostrador para exhibir mejor sus dulces. Con el tiempo tuvo la buena idea de acondicionar una pequeña bodega en su casa, compró un poco de gaseosas y abarrotes. Por medio de un familiar pudo integrar el Banco Comunal “Mujeres con Futuro” en este grupo obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con el cual compró varias cajas de gaseosas. Con el último préstamo que también es de S/. 300.00 y que cancelará en 4 meses comprará dos cajas de cerveza, un poco de abarrotes y golosinas. Su mayor sueño es tener un negocio más grande debido a que en la zona existe demanda porque es un lugar por donde tienen que pasar obligatoriamente los pasajeros que van a Julcán y a Mache.

loans.use: To purchase boxes of beer and various goods for her store

loans.name: La Hoyada 23 De Marzo Group

texts.es:
La Hoyada 23 de marzo is the name of an association of 17 women who carry out many activities in order to survive. It is a great sacrifice, but is the only way in which to earn a living and to meet the demands of being the mother of a family.

Bread, crafts, textiles, knitting, socks, perfumes and baby clothes and toys are some of the the products on offer, sold by walking around in markets and squares in the city of El Alto.

They all work every season of the year, and this is why this group would like capital to invest in their businesses so that they can vary and increase their wares by satisfying the current demand, and thereby earning the money they so desperately need.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La Hoyada 23 de marzo, es el nombre de la asociación que reúne a un grupo de 17 mujeres que para poder sobrevivir se dedican a muchas actividades que les representan sacrificio, pero es el único camino para poder generar sus recursos y hacer frente a las obligaciones que les demanda el ser madres de familia. La venta de pan, la venta de artesanías, textiles, tejidos, calzados, perfumes y artículos de bebé, son algunos de los productos que son ofertados de forma ambulante en las ferias y plazas principales de la ciudad de El Alto. Todas aprovechan las distintas temporadas que se dan en el año, por tal motivo, este grupo de socias precisan de capital para invertir en sus negocios y poder variar e incrementar sus mercaderías con el fin de satisfacer la demanda existente, de esta manera generar sus ganancias que tanta falta deshace.

loans.use: This member group needs capital to invest in their businesses so that they can vary and increase their wares so that they can satisfy current demand and in this way earn more than they spend / este grupo de socias precisan de capital para invertir en sus negocios y poder variar e incrementar sus mercaderías con el fin de satisfacer la demanda existente, de esta manera generar sus ganancias que tanta falta deshace

loans.name: Nieves Lola

texts.es:
Nieves Lola G. Zavaleta lives in Mache district, Otuzco province, La Libertad department, Peru. She is 44 years old and has 3 dependent children. She studied through middle school.

Fifteen years ago she lived in the city of Trujillo and traveled frequently to the mountains of La Libertad, especially to the districts of Mache and Julcán. There she bought ham, mutton, and pork, which she sold in the wholesaler’s market in Trujillo. Since marrying she has lived in the district of Mache and continued with the same type of business. Little by little, she became well known, and she now has a good clientele. In addition to selling meat, she also has a small grocery store in her home, where she sells basic goods. On the weekends she travels to Julcán, where she has a stand from which she sells threads, buttons, zippers, fabrics, etc.

She joined the “Mujeres de Trabajo” communal bank at the invitation of a cousin. She obtained her first loan of S/.300.00, with which she bought sewing notions so she could sell them in her community.

With this loan of S/. 1000.00, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy 1 sack of rice, 1 sack of sugar, a box of cooking oil, and sewing notions to sell at her stand.

Nieves’ dream is for her children become professionals and for her business to continue prospering.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Nieves Lola G. Zavaleta vive en el distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco del departamento La Libertad. Tiene 44 años de edad, con 3 hijos que aun dependen de ella, su grado de instrucción es secundaria completa. Hace quince años vivía en la ciudad de Trujillo, viajaba constantemente a la sierra de La Libertad especialmente a los distritos de Mache y Julcán, compraba jamón, carne de carnero y de cerdo el cual ofrecía en el mercado mayorista de la ciudad de Trujillo; desde que se casó vino a radicar al distrito de Mache y allí continuó su negocio, poco a poco se hizo conocida y actualmente tiene una buena clientela. Además de vender carne tiene una bodega en su casa en donde vende productos de primera necesidad; los fines de semana viaja a Julcán, allí ha conseguido un puesto en el que vende hilos, botones, cierres, blondas, etc. Ingresó al Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Trabajo” por invitación de una prima, en el cual obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero tuvo la iniciativa de viajar a Julcán para comprar todo lo que es mercería y poder vender por su comunidad. Con el préstamo de S/.1000.00 que pagará en 4 meses, comprara 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, una caja de aceite y materiales de costura que vende en su puesto. La señora Nieves sueña con ver a sus hijos profesionales y seguir prosperando en su negocio.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy basic goods products to sell in her small grocery store

loans.name: Nila Violeta

texts.es:
Mrs. Nila Violeta Z. C. lives in the district of Agallpampa in Otuzco province in the city of La Libertad, Peru. She is 39 years old and studied through the fourth year of secondary school. She has four dependent children.

Nila has a small grocery store in her home. She has a very good clientele because all the cars that travel to the outlying provinces outside La Libertad stop in Agallpampa at a police control and the passengers take advantage of the stop to do their shopping.

Nila is a member of the Communal Bank “Jesús Nazareno” (Jesus the Nazarene) from which she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00 (approximately $100 U.S.). With that loan she purchased bread, soft drinks, and snacks to sell in her small shop.

With a loan of S/.1,000.00 (approximately $350 U.S.) that she will repay in 6 months, Nila will purchase a box of soft drinks, a bag of rice, a bag of sugar, a box of tuna and a package of noodles.

Nila’s dream is to expand her store, to purchase wood to resell, and to purchase a vehicle for transport.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Nila Violeta Z. C. vive en el distrito de Agallpampa provincia de Otuzco del departamento La Libertad – Perú. Tiene 39 años de edad, estudio hasta el cuarto año de secundaria y tiene 4 hijos que aun dependen de ella. La señora Nila tiene una pequeña bodega en su domicilio y tiene también muy buena clientela debido a que todos los carros que van a la mayoría de provincias de la sierra de La Libertad paran en Agallpampa para un control policial y los pasajeros aprovechan para realizar compras. Es socia del Banco Comunal “Jesús Nazareno” en el que obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con el cual compró pan, gaseosas y abarrotes para ofrecer en su pequeño negocio. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 que cancelará en 6 meses comprará una caja de gaseosas, un saco de arroz, un saco de azúcar, una caja de atún y un paquete de fideos. El sueño de la señora Nila es ampliar más su tienda, comprar madera para volver a vender así también un vehículo para transportarse.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks, rice, sugar and other products

loans.name: Santos Evelia

texts.es:
Santos Evelia Rodríguez A. is 40 years old. She lives in Mache district, Otuzco province, La Libertad department, Peru. She has three dependent children.

Over time she has become a very successful businesswoman. Currently, she has an agriculture/veterinary supply store called “Otiniano”, where she sells plant medicines, fertilizers and insecticides (in both powder and liquid forms), pesticides, and other products for agricultural activities. At her business, she has installed a small vitrine in which she displays hardware products.

She studied Accounting, and when she finished her studies, she got a job with the municipality of Mache, where she worked for 6 years. She later married and started a family. Due to the need to stay at home to care for her children, she got the idea of starting up the business she currently has. Things have gone well for her, since she is the only person in the neighborhood who sells these products. She has always noticed the unmet needs of consumers and realized that there was no good place for visitors to stay in Mache, so she opened a small hostel.

She is one of the founding members of the “Mujeres con Futuro” (Women with a Future) communal bank, which she joined 5 years ago. The first loan she received was for S/. 300.00 and she used the money to start her agriculture/veterinary supply store.

With this loan of S/. 2000.00, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy 1 box of Hieloxil, a product that is used to cure infections of potato plants and which is very much in demand during this season; 1 box of Tifón, which is for killing weevils; and 1 box of Extrafox.

Santos dreams of having another business location, which she would make into a large and modern hardware store.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Santos Evelia Rodríguez A. tiene 40 años de edad. Vive en el distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad – Perú. Tiene tres hijos que aun dependen de ella. A través del tiempo se ha convertido en una comerciante muy exitosa, actualmente tiene una Agro veterinaria llamada “Otiniano”, lugar donde se venden productos medicinales para la siembra, fertilizantes y exterminadores de insectos ya sea en polvo o liquido; pesticidas y otros productos especiales para el agro. En este mismo negocio a colocado una pequeña vitrina en la que exhibe productos de ferretería. Estudio la carrera de Contabilidad y al terminar sus estudios consiguió un trabajo en la municipalidad de Mache en la cual trabajó 6 años, posteriormente se caso y formó su familia debido a la necesidad de quedarse en su casa a cuidar de sus niños tuvo la idea de poner el negocio que actualmente mantiene y le ha ido muy bien ya que ella es única en la zona que vende estos productos. Siempre ha observado las necesidades no cubiertas de los consumidores y se dio cuenta que en Mache no existía un lugar apropiado donde puedan alojarse los visitantes y es así que abrió un pequeño hostal. Es una de las fundadoras del Banco Comunal “Mujeres con Futuro” hace cinco años que es socia de este banco comunal. El primer préstamo que recibió fue de S/. 300.00 con este dinero implemento su negocio agrícola. Con el préstamo de S/.2000.00 el cual pagara en 4 meses comprará 1 caja de hieloxil producto que sirve para curar los sembríos de papa el cual los agricultores solicitan mayormente en esta época, 1 caja de tifón que sirve para exterminar el gorgojo y 1 caja de extrafox. La señora Santos sueña con tener otro local en el que acondicione una ferretería moderna y amplia.

loans.use: To buy inventory of products for her business

loans.name: Maria Del Pilar

texts.es:
Mrs. María del Pilar A. V. lives in the district of Agallpampa in Otuzco province in the city of La Libertad, Peru. She is 36 years old with a high school education. She also has two grown children.

When María was young she worked as a housekeeper and she saved what she earned in order to begin her own business. In this way she slowly started a grocery store in her own home in which she sells basic foods and beauty products.

María is part of the Communal Bank “Jesús Nazareno” (“Jesus of Nazareth”) and from this communal bank she received her first loan of S/. 300.00 (approximately $100 U.S.). With this money she purchased various products to supply her store.

With a loan of S/. 1000.00 ($350 U.S.) that she will repay in 6 months, María will buy 1 box of oil, noodles, rice, and beauty products, especially perfume and cologne.

María dreams of building her business.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora María del Pilar A. V. vive en el distrito de Agallpampa en la provincia de Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad – Perú; tiene 36 años de edad y estudió secundaria completa. Tiene dos hijos que aun dependen de ella. Cuando era más joven trabajaba como empleada del hogar y lo que ganaba lo iba ahorrando para poner su negocio de esa forma lentamente implementa una pequeña bodega en su casa en la que ofrece productos de primera necesidad y productos de belleza. Es socia del Banco Comunal “Jesús Nazareno” en este banco comunal recibió un primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compró varios productos para surtir su bodega. Con el préstamo de S/. 1000.00 que pagará en 6 meses, comprará 1 caja de aceite, fideos, arroz y productos de belleza especialmente perfumes y colonias. La señora Maria sueña con ampliar mas su negocio

loans.use: To purchase products to supply a general store

loans.name: Antofagasta Group

texts.es:
Antofagasta is the name of the association that unites 18 women, lead by Leonarda Beatriz P., and who have many different types of business.

Mainly, their activities include crafts and textiles, mainly using lamb's wool and alpaca wool. These products are sold in the main market in the city of El Alto, and some places in La Paz.

Unfortunately, raw material for these kinds of crafts is very expensive, especially when buying in small quantities. For this reason they need money to invest in buying raw material in bulk, which will definitely have a positive impact on their economies, reducing the cost of buying raw material.

It is only in this way that they will see an increase in their income, as at the moment their wares are selling well.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Antofagasta, es el nombre de la asociación que reúne a 18 mujeres liderizadas por la señora Leonarda Beatriz P. y que se dedican al comercio de todo tipo de productos.

Entre sus principales destrezas se encuentra la elaboración de artesanías, textiles, principalmente en lana de oveja y lana de alpaca. Estos productos son comercializados en la feria principal de la ciudad de El Alto, y en algunas zonas de la ciudad de La Paz.

Lastimosamente la materia prima para este tipo de artesanías, es muy costosa, y más cuando se realiza la compra por menor o por unidad. Por tal motivo, ellas precisan de capital para poder invertir en la compra de materia prima al por mayor, lo que definitivamente tendrá un impacto positivo en su economía, pues se reducirá el gasto que genera la compra de esta materia prima.

Solo de esta manera podrán ver un ligero incremento en sus ingresos, puesto que la venta de estos artículos por el momento es unitario.

loans.use: They need the capital to invest in buying mostly raw materials, which will definitely have a positive impact on their economies, and this will reduce their spending on this material.

loans.name: Rocio Del Pilar

texts.es:
Rocío Del Pilar A. Sánchez is 37 years old and studied through primary school. She has 4 dependent children. She lives in Agallpampa district, Otuzco province, La Libertad department.

Her business consists of buying animals such as cattle, guinea pigs, and chickens, which she then sells on Sundays at the Julcán market in Agallpampa. Before she began this business, she prepared and sold salchipollo (French fries with fried chicken), salchipapa (French fries with sausage), and fried fish. It didn’t work out well for her because she working in an area where there wasn’t much commercial activity; so, she quit that business and began selling livestock animals.

She is a member of the “Jesús Nazareno” communal bank, from which she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00. With that money she bought 1 sack of potatoes, cooking oil, and vegetables, for preparing the foods she was selling at that time. With this loan of S/. 1000.00, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy 10 chickens, 15 guinea pigs, and 5 ducks. Rocío's dream is for her children to be educated and have good livelihoods.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rocío Del Pilar A. Sánchez tiene 37 años de edad, estudió solo primaria completa. Tiene 4 hijos y todos dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Agallpampa en la provincia de Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad. Su negocio consiste en la compra y venta de animales como huachos, reses, cuyes y gallinas, los cuales ofrece y vende los domingos en la feria de Julcán y Agallpampa. Antes que entrara a este negocio, se dedicaba a preparar y vender salchipollo, salchipapa y pescado frito, no le iba muy bien ya que por la zona no había movimiento, por eso dejó ese negocio y se dedicó a la venta de animales. Ella integra el Banco Comunal “Jesús Nazareno” en el que obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compró 1 saco de papas, aceite, verduras; para la preparación de los alimentos que en ese entonces vendía. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 10 gallinas, 15 cuyes y 5 patos. La señora Roció sueña con ver a sus hijos realizados.

loans.use: She will buy 10 chickens, 15 guinea pigs, and 5 ducks

loans.name: Maria Avelina

texts.es:
Maria Avelina G. D. ValverD. is 50 years old and studied through 5th graD.. She has four children, none of whom are still dependent. She lives in the Agallpampa district, in Otuzco province, La Libertad department, Peru.

Her business consists of buying and selling animals such as cattle, guinea pigs, and chickens, which she slaughters on Saturdays so she can sell them on Sundays at the Julcán market in Agallpampa.

She is very happy with what she is doing now, because previously she only planted food crops. She is a member of the communal bank “Jesús Nazareno”, from which she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00. With that money she bought chickens and guinea pigs.

With this loan of S/. 1000.00, which she will repay within 6 months, she will buy 10 hens, 20 guinea pigs, and 5 sheep.

Maria’s dream is to move to the city of Trujillo and open a business there.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Avelina G. D. ValverD. tiene 50 años D. edad, estudio hasta el quinto grado D. primaria. Tiene cuatro hijos que ya no dependen D. ella. Vive en el distrito D. Agallpampa en la provincia D. Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad - Perú Su negocio consiste en la compra y venta D. animales como huachos, reses, cuyes y gallinas, los cuales sacrifica los días sábados para ofrecerlos y venderlos al siguiente día en la feria D. Julcán y Agallpampa. Está muy contenta con lo que hace actualmente ya que anteriormente solo se dedicaba a la chacra. Ella integra el Banco Comunal “Jesús Nazareno” en el que obtuvo su primer préstamo D. S/. 300.00 con este dinero compró gallinas y cuyes. Con el préstamo D. S/. 1,000.00 el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará 10 gallinas, 20 cuyes y 5 carneros. La señora Maria sueña con radicar en la ciudad D. Trujillo y poner allí un negocio.

loans.use: With this loan she will buy 10 chickens, 20 guinea pigs, and 5 sheep

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
Maria R. is 36 years old and she studied through middle school. She has two dependent children. She lives in the district of Mache, in the province of Otuzcu, in La Libertad department, Peru.

She buys and sells cereal grains, such as wheat, barley, and dried peas. She also has farm plot where she plants potatoes. She sells all of these products in the city of Trujillo. Aside from this business, she also raises small livestock animals: guinea pigs, turkeys, and chickens, which she later sells.

Her mother-in-law introduced her to the communal bank “Mujeres de Mache” (Women of Mache), where she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00. With this money she bought two turkeys and some guinea pigs. It was around Christmas time and she wanted to take advantage of the good opportunity to sell these animals.

With this loan of S/. 2,200.00, which she will pay back in four months, she will buy two average-sized bulls.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria R. tiene 36 años de edad, estudió secundaria completa. Tiene dos hijos que aun dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco en el departamento de La Libertad - Perú Se dedica a la compra y venta de cereales tales como trigo, cebada, alverja, además tiene su chacra en la que siembra papa, todos estos productos los lleva a vender a la ciudad de Trujillo. A parte de este negocio también cría animales menores: cuyes, pavos y gallinas para venderlos posteriormente. Por medio de su suegra ingresa al Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Mache” en el que obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compro dos pavos y cuyes ya que por ese tiempo era campaña navideña y quería aprovechar en vender estos animales. Con el préstamo de S/.2,200.00 el cual pagará en cuatro meses comprará dos toros de regular tamaño.

loans.use: With this loan she will buy 2 bulls

loans.name: Ermida

texts.es:
Mrs. Ermida L. S. lives in the district of Agallpampa in Otuzco province in the city of La Libertad, Peru. She studied through the fifth year of secondary school, and she has five dependent children.

At forty years of age, Ermida dedicates herself to the purchase and sale of animals such as cows, pigs, and sheep. She sells them in different parts of the country around La Libertad as well as near the coast, especially in Trujillo.

Ermida belongs to the communal bank “Jesús Nazareno” (Jesus the Nazarene) through which she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00 (approximately $100.00 U.S.). She invested this money in the purchase of four pigs. She is currently requesting a loan of S/. 1,200.00 (approximately $400 U.S.) to be repaid in 6 months. She will purchase a cow and 8 pigs, animals which she will raise in order to resell at a higher price.

Ermida is the secretary of her communal bank. Her dream is to increase her business sales.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Ermida L. S. vive en el distrito de Agallpampa en la provincia de Otuzco en el departamento de La Libertad –Perú. Estudio hasta el quinto año de secundaria, tiene dos hijos que aun dependen de ella. A sus 40 años de edad se dedica a la compra y venta de animales tales como: reses, cerdos y carneros, los cuales ofrece y vende por diferentes partes de la sierra liberteña así también por la costa especialmente Trujillo. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Jesús Nazareno” en el que obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 este dinero lo invirtió en la compra de cuatro cerdos. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,200.00 el cual pagara en 6 meses, comprará una vaca y ocho cerdos; animales que criara para su posterior venta a mayor precio. La señora Ermida Es secretaria de su banco comunal. Su sueño es incrementar las ventas en su negocio.

loans.use: To purchase a cow and eight pigs

loans.name: Nelly Rosa

texts.es:
Mrs. Nelly Rosa A. Z. is 50 years old and completed her education through elementary school. She has three dependent children. She lives in the district of Agallpampa in the province of Otuzco in the city of La Libertad, Peru.

Nelly dedicates herself to the sale of animals such as pigs, sheep and bulls. She butchers them and sells their meat in distinct places in the country around La Libertad. She began the business with her husband, but after encountering some difficulties she decided to work alone and she is very happy with the results that she has obtained.

Through some neighbors she was able to join the communal bank “Jesús Nazareno” (Jesus the Nazarene). Through the bank she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00 (approximately $100.00 U.S.). With this money she purchased two rams.

She is asking for a loan of S/. 1500.00 (approximately $500 U.S.) which she will repay in 6 months. She plans to purchase four rams and a cow.

Nelly dreams of starting a store in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Nelly Rosa A. Z. tiene 50 años de edad, estudió solo primaria completa. Tiene tres hijos que aun dependen de ella. Vive en el Distrito de Agallpampa de la Provincia de Otuzco del Departamento de La Libertad – Perú. La señora Nelly se dedica a la compra de animales como cerdos, ovejas y toros para sacrificarlos y vender sus carne por distintos lugares de la sierra liberteña, este negocio lo inició con su esposo pero después de pasar algunas dificultades decidió dedicarse sola a esta actividad y se siente muy contenta por los resultados que obtiene. Por medio de unas vecinas pudo integrarse al banco comunal “Jesús Nazareno” En este banco comunal obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 con este dinero compró dos carneros. Con el préstamo de S/.1500.00 que cancelará en un periodo de 6 meses comprará 4 carneros y una vaca. La señora Nelly sueña con implementar una tienda en su casa.

loans.use: To purchase 4 rams and a cow

loans.name: Magda Violeta

texts.es:
Magda Violeta Iba I. Ríos is 44 years old. She studied through the fifth grade of primary school. She has three dependent children. She lives in Agallpampa district, Otuzco province, La Libertad department, Peru.

Her business consists of buying cattle, guinea pigs, and chickens, which she slaughters to sell the meat to different restaurants in the city of Trujillo. She is happy with her business because she has helped to cover the basic necessities of her family, which previously had fewer financial resources since she was only working as a farmer and raising a few livestock animals, almost all for domestic consumption.

She is a member of the “Jesús Nazareno” community bank, which is where she obtained her first loan of S./ 300.00. With that money she bought three sheep. With this loan of S/. 500.00, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will buy 5 sheep. Magda’s dream is that her children will be educated and have good professions.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Magda Violeta I. Ríos tiene 44 años de edad, estudió hasta el quinto grado de primaria. Tiene tres hijos que aun dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Agallpampa en la provincia de Otuzco en el departamento La Libertad - Perú Su negocio consiste en la compra y venta de animales como huachos, reses, cuyes y gallinas, los cuales sacrifica para ofrecer y vender la carne por diferentes restaurantes de la ciudad de Trujillo. Se siente satisfecha con su negocio porque le ha ayudado a cubrir las necesidades de su familia la cual anteriormente tenía muchas más carencias ya que solo se dedicaba a la chacra y al acrianza de pocos animales sobre todo para el consumo. Ella integra el Banco Comunal “Jesús Nazareno” en el que obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compró tres carneros. Con el préstamo de S/. 500.00 el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 5 carneros La señora Magda sueña con ver a sus hijos realizados.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy 5 sheep

loans.name: Merta Nadi Group

texts.id:
Merta Nadi is a group of pig farmers located in the village of Candikusuma where the majority of people are Hindu. The name Merta Nadi was chosen by the members of the group because Merti means "immediate" and Nadi means "prosperity" and Nadi is also the name of the street they live on. With all of their enthusiasm, Merta Nadi approached Denari to help them make raising pigs the right way easier. Merta Nadi is asking for a loan to purchase high-quality pig feed, to help their sick pigs get well and to unsure that the control of their money is good in order. After creation and training, Dinari now feels that the Merta Nadi group is ready to receive funding. Merta Nadi consists of leader Ni Komang Santiani, secretary Ni Ketut Suari dan treasurer Ni Ketut Kongsi. Merta Nadi has a total of 11 members. The loan will be used to purchase a high quality boar and quality pig feed. With these improvements the pigs they raise will be much higher quality than the pigs typically raised in their village. All along, the members of Merta Nadi have been very diligent in their work. With the help from the loan they receive the members of Merta Nadi believe that their business undertaking will be a success and really take off.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Merta Nadi sebuah kelompok ternak Babi yang berlokasi di desa Candikusuma dimana sebagian besar masyarakatnya memeluk agama Hindu. Nama ini diberikan atas persetujuan anggota karena mempunyai arti bahwa Merta itu berarti Rejeki atau berkat sedangkan Nadi merupakan suatu jalan kehidupan. Sehingga Merta Nadi diberi arti oleh anggota kelompok kehidupan yang dipenuhi rejeki. Dengan keyakinan inilah anggota akhirnya mengajukan permohonan kepada Yayasan Dinari untuk mendapat pembinaan mengenai beternak babi seperti bagaimana cara beternak babi yang baik dan benar,cara pemberian pakan yang bagus, mengatasi penyakit babi secara cepat dan tepat,serta pengaturan keuangan yang benar agar modal untuk pakan ternak tidak habis untuk biaya dapur. Setelah pembinaan dan pelatihan dirasa cukup maka Yayasan Dinari memberi pinjaman modal kepada anggota kelompok Merta Nadi. Kelompok ini diketuai oleh Ni Komang Santiani ,Sekretaris Ni Ketut Suari dan Bendahara Ni Ketut Kongsi. Dengan jumlah anggota sebanyak 11 orang. Pinjaman modal yang diberikan oleh Yayasan Dinari dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit unggul dan pakan ternak yang berkwalitas,maksudnya agar hasil yang diperoleh akan lebih bagus daripada memelihara babi lokal, yang selama ini mereka tekuni. Dengan adanya pembinaan dan dukungan modal dari Yayasan Dinari maka kelompok Merta Nadi berkeyakinan bahwa usahanya akan sukses dan berkembang bagus.

loans.use: to purchase a high quality boar and quality pig feed

loans.name: Ni Nengah Purnami

texts.id:
Ni Nengah Purnami works hard to raise cattle. Her work hasn't lessened since she married her husband Putu Merta. Her efforts in raising cattle have been recognized by her village organization since she was selected to receive a loan via Kiva and Dinari.
