When the group was asked what their dreams for the future were, it was Tarcila’s answer that stood out. First she said she wanted to own a home so that she would have something to leave her children. She began to cry when she confessed that she had recently found out she had a possibly fatal illness that doctors could not cure. The other two associates comforted her by telling her hopeful stories about their own experiences with illness.

Cruzkaya, Francisca, and Tarcila need loans of 600, 600, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy artisan products, fabric, thread, zippers, elastic, and used clothing.

loans.use: Cruzkaya, Francisca, and Tarcila need loans of 600, 600, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy artisan products, fabric, thread, zippers, elastic, and used clothing.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith M. Q. is thirty-one years old. She is separated form her partner and is raising their five children with no help from him. Edith has been a member of the community bank “Minka” for two years. She was unable to access credit before joining the community bank because she had nothing to use as collateral. In the community bank she has found support and learned how to laugh.

In the past Edith sold shish kabobs from a cart. Since joining the community bank she has been able to start selling kitchen appliances and repair parts. She travels nine hours once or twice per week to the city of Lima to buy kitchen products and sell them in Ayacucho.

Edith needs a loan of 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will use to buy more kitchen appliances.

Edith dreams of opening a store, and that her children will have a better life. She is making plans to open a store in the next couple of months. She has rented a location and is engaged in negotiation with the previous tenant.

loans.use: Edith needs a loan of 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will use to buy more kitchen appliances.

loans.name: Zilghian Julisa

texts.es:
Zilgian is a 29 years old entrepreneur who lives in the 3-80 neighborhood. This young woman, eager to start her own business, decided to start a family business with her sister, using the capital they were able to accrue by saving part of their salaries. The sisters identified the opportunity of opening an Internet café at their mother’s house, as there were no other competitor businesses in the area. They have run the business for three years and they offer a variety of services, which have diversified as their clientele grows. The small business has five web access computers, a photocopier and two phone cabins for international and local calls. In order to increase their income, they plan to acquire a greater number of computers, a spiral binding machine and a scanner. But Zligian’s priority at present is to renovate and repaint the store, in order to improve its appearance. The income from the business has allowed this family to improve their living conditions. The sisters are very satisfied with what they have accomplished together in spite of their young age.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Zilgian es una joven microempresaria de 29 años de edad, habita en el barrio 3-80. Esta joven deseosa de iniciar su propio negocio decide junto a su hermana de 21 años emprender un negocio familiar, con capital propio, ya que siempre han ahorrado parte de los ingresos que percibían de su trabajo. Las hermanas vieron la necesidad de montar un Cyber Café en la vivienda de su madre, ya que en esa zona no existe ningún Cyber que le pueda generar competencia. El negocio ya tiene tres años de existencia, y ofrece una variedad de servicios, los cuales se han ido diversificando a medida que va aumentando el número de clientes. El negocio es pequeño y cuenta con cinco computadoras con servicio de Internet, una fotocopiadora y dos cabinas para realizar llamadas nacionales e internacionales. Las expectativas de estas jóvenes son las de adquirir un mayor número de máquinas, comprar una encolochadora y un escáner, de modo de aumentar sus ganancias. La prioridad de Zligian en estos momentos es la remodelar las paredes del local y pintarlo, dando así una mejor presentación al negocio. Los ingresos del negocio le han permitido a esta familia mejorar su nivel de vida y vivir en condiciones dignas. Las hermanas se sienten satisfechas con lo que juntas han logrado, a pesar de su corta edad.

loans.use: Purchase of cement, sand, iron, stone and paint.

loans.name: Diana Aurora

texts.es:
Diana began selling perfumes in February 2003. She had sold clothing and cosmetics before but after finding that a well-known perfume shop in her neighborhood sold perfumes at wholesale prices, she began selling perfumes. Her business has gone well, selling first to friends and, little by little, to others who have been recommended to her. Thanks to this business, Diana can help her husband, who doesn't earn much, with the school expenses of their two children.

Diana now wants to buy more merchandise so that she can have a wider range for her customers. Consequently, she's asking for a US$925 loan, to be repaid in 6 months, that she can use to help her family get ahead. With the additional products she'll buy, she'll attract more customers. With your help, Diana can get ahead and help her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Diana comenzó a vender perfumes en Febrero del 2003 primero vendiendo ropa y cosméticos, pero después se enteró de una reconocida casa de perfumes de la localidad que vendía a precios de mayoreo y fue así como empezó con la venta de perfumes y le fue muy bien, primero entres sus amistades y actualmente en su casa tiene un letrero donde se anuncia, poco a poco la gente va reconociendo el establecimiento de Diana. Gracias a esto Diana a logrado brindarle un apoyo a su esposo que no gana mucho y con la ayuda de Diana han logrado pagar los gastos de sus dos hijos en la escuela.

Sin embargo Diana, desea comprar más mercancía para poder tener variedad para sus clientes. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $925 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Diana podrá sacar adelante a su familia, ya que con los productos que comprará, tendrá más gente que le compre. Con tu ayuda Diana logrará salir adelante y ayudar a su esposo.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Eteldita

texts.es:
Eteldita is a member of Las Doncellas comunal bank, located in AA.HH. Primavera II etapa Mz. 26 Lt. 23, Manatay district, department of Ucayali. She is a 33 year old mother to three children, and her husband is a vendor. With the first loan of 300 soles that she received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in the purchase and sale of beauty products.

Currently she continues to sell beauty products of a wide variety of brands, and also does work such as manicures. Because of her work, she needs to constantly be out looking for clients and collecting payments, but she also makes time to be with her family.

With this loan of 1000 soles, which she will repay in 4 months, she will invest in the purchase of beauty products such as perfumes, shadows, powders, creams, etc., and nail polishes of different colors.

When Eteldita began this business, she started with a few products, but thanks to the loans from Manuela Ramos, she has been purchasing more and her income is increasing which will help her family.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Eteldita pertenece al banco comunal Las Doncellas, ubicado en el AA. HH. Primavera II etapa Mz. 26 Lt. 23, distrito de Manantay, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 33 años, es madre de 3 hijos y su esposo es comerciante. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la compra y venta de productos de belleza.

En la actualidad sigue vendiendo productos de belleza de diversas marcas, así como también realiza trabajos de manicura, por motivo de los negocios tiene que salir constantemente a buscar clientes y para realizar cobranzas, pero se da un tiempo para estar en familia.

Con el préstamo de S/.1,000, el cual pagará en 4 meses, invertirá en la compra de productos de belleza como perfumes, sombras, talcos, cremas, etc., y esmaltes de diferentes colores.

Cuando Eteldita se inició en el negocio empezó con pocos productos gracias a los préstamos recibidos de Manuela Ramos está comprando más y sus ingresos aumentan para el bien de su familia.

loans.use: Purchase beauty products

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Señora Rosa belongs to the communal bank "Mujeres Valientes" (Brave Women), which is located at 296 Jr. Lima N°in the district of Calleria in the department of Ucayali. She is 59-years-old, has 6 children, is married, and her husband is a merchant.

Currently, the grocery store that she owns has grown more. Now she sells more products than before with the support of her children, who take turns attending to the store. At night, she sells regional food outside her home.

With this loan of 1,500 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in the purchase of rice, sugar, milk, noodles, etc., and supplies to prepare the food that she sells.

Rosa has a very noble character and is very kind. This is why her grocery store is very frequented and loved by her neighbors. She tells us that it's always nice to have a smile for someone. She is also very thankful to Manuela Ramos for all of the support offered to her.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Rosa pertenece al banco comunal Mujeres Valientes, ubicado en el Jr. Lima N° 296, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 59 años, 6 hijos, es casada y su esposo es comerciante.

En la actualidad la bodega que posee ha crecido más, ahora vende mas productos que antes con el apoyo de sus hijos, los cuales se turnan para la atención y en las noches vende comida regional en la vereda de su casa.

Con el préstamo de S/.1,500, el cual pagará en 4 meses, invertirá en la compra de arroz, azúcar, leche, fideos, etc., y víveres para la venta de sus comidas.

Rosa tiene una carácter muy noble y es muy bondadosa, es por eso que su bodega es muy concurrida y es muy querida por sus vecinos, siempre es bueno tener una sonrisa para alguien, nos dice ella, además está muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos por todo el apoyo brindado.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries (rice, sugar, milk, etc.) and supplies to prepare food

loans.name: Rosita Miscksy

texts.es:
Rosita goes to the comunal bank of Las Doncellas, located in AA. HH. Primavera II etapa Mz. 30 Lt. 5, District of Manantay, department of Ucayali. She is 29 years old and is the mother of two children. She maintains her living with her small groceries store. She gets up early every morning to make breakfast for her family and then goes to work. (Rosita is also grateful for Manuela Ramos’s help, which allows her to work from home and be more independent while spending more time with her children.) With a loan of 1000 soles, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will be able to invest in a bag of rice, a bag of sugar, half a carton of milk and soda for her store. Please help her with this investment.

Translated by Lily Fu, Princeton University Language Project

La señora Rosita pertenece al banco comunal Las Doncellas, ubicado en el AA. HH. Primavera II etapa Mz. 30 Lt. 5, distrito de Manantay, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 29 años y es madre de 2 hijos. En la actualidad cuenta con un motocarro y una bodega. Se levanta muy temprano para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos y esposo y atender su venta. Con el préstamo de S/.1,000 el cual pagará en 4 meses, invertirá en la compra de 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, ½ caja de leche y gaseosas, los cuales le permitirán implementar más su bodega. Rosita está agradecida con el apoyo de Manuela Ramos porque puede trabajar de manera independiente sin salir de su casa, eso le permite estar más tiempo con sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase Groceries (rice, sugar, milk, etc.)

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
Virginia belongs to the Community Bank Mujeres Valientes, located in Jr. Guillermo Sisley S/N, Calleria, in Ucayali. She is 57 years old, a mother of three, whose husband works in retail. At the moment she has a shop selling spare car parts, as well as a garage. She works with her husband and children, who share the different roles within the business and domestic tasks. With the loan of S/.3000 which she received from Manuela Ramos, which she will pay within 4 months, she will invest in the purchase of car parts such as tyres, tyre chains, balance wheels, gears, fixed wheels, etc. And the rest of the money will be invested in the maintenance of the garage. Virginia’s family-run business is growing, as is her income, which is creating more capital, allowing her to continue buying products. Furthermore, she is happy with all she has achieved so far.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

La señora Virgnia pertenece al banco comunal Mujeres Valientes, ubicado en el Jr. Guillermo Sisley S/N, distrito D. Calleria, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 57 años, es madre D. 3 hijos y su esposo es comerciante. En la actualidad tiene una tienda D. venta D. repuestos D. motos, también un taller D. mecánica. Trabaja junto a su esposo e hijos y se distribuyen distintas funciones en el negocio y en las labores domésticas. Con el préstamo que recibió D. Manuela Ramos D. S/.3,000, el cual pagará en 4 meses, invertirá en la compra D. repuestos D. motos como llantas, cadenas, catalinas, rodajes, piñones, etc. y otra parte del capital lo destinará al taller D. mecánica para su mantenimiento. Virginia, con el trabajo familiar que realiza en el negocio, éste está creciendo al igual que sus ingresos, los cuales generan mayor capital para seguir comprando más productos, además está muy feliz D. todos lo logros obtenidos hasta el momento.

loans.use: To purchase spare car parts

loans.name: Julia Lionila

texts.es:
Julia Lionila C. Alfonso, who belongs to the Community Bank “Mujeres de Grandes Retos”, sells fabric. Her business is located in the district and province of Huaraz, in Ancash. With her previous loan of S/.1500 she has bought fabric, thus increasing her income. She will invest this new loan of S/. 3000, which will be paid off within 4 months, in buying greater quantities of fabric, of different quality, in order to supply her business with more products and increase sales. She is 49 years old, a single mother with 4 children who are now adults. Her income enables her to support her grandchildren.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

La señora Julia Lionila C. Alfonso, pertence al “Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Grandes Retos”, ella se dedica ala venta de telas, su negocio esta ubicado en el distrito y provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash, Con el préstamo anterior de S/. 1,500 nuevos soles, ha comprado telas al por mayor incrementando sus ingresos, Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000.00 nuevos soles el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en comprar mas cantidad de telas de distintas calidades par surtir su negocio e incrementar sus ventas. Ella tiene 49 años de edad es madre soltera y tiene 4 hijos, los cuales ya son independientes, su ingreso le permite ayudar a su nietos.

loans.use: The loan will be used to buy fabric for her business

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Mrs.Julia S. C. is 48 years old and attended school up to the third grade. She has four children that no longer live with her. She lives in Asentamiento Humano Víctor Raúl in the Porvenir District, Trujillo Province of La Libertad Department of Peru

Her business in the summer is selling sandals and in the winter she sells more rugged footwear. Her sales route takes her to northern cities like Sullana and Tambo Grande. To complement her ernings, she owns a taxi which operates from Trujillo to Asentamiento Humano Gran Chimú.

Mrs.Julia began selling plastic products such as buckets but her earnings were insufficient. She decided to change her product offering to shoes and began making enough money for her to purchase the taxi. Mrs.Julia belongs to the communal bank "Millenium Women", which is where she obtained her first microcredit to purchase plastic products.

The microcredit she is requesting will be used to fix a broken pump in her taxi. She also plans to purchase two dozen sandals to sell to her female clientele.

Mrs.Julia´s dream is to purchase a second taxi which her husband would drive along the same route. A second taxi would allow her to maximize the potential of this busy route.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: Car repair and purchase sandals to sell

loans.name: Constatina's Group

texts.en:
Constatina and Neli have been members of the community bank “Ollantay II” for thirteen and eight years respectively. In that time they have learned about responsibility and punctuality. They have learned how to treat their children and have healthy relationships with their family.

Constatina is 42 years old. She lives with her partner and three daughters. Constatina has a small store where she sells food staples such as flour, sugar, and rice. She opened her store seven months ago. Before opening her store she worked as an artisan with her brother. When he passed away she found herself unable to continue in that line of work.

Neli is 35 years old. She is married and has two children. Neli sells wood products for building. In addition, she makes and sells furniture. She has been running this business for seventeen years. She travels eight hours by poor roads to the jungle area to buy wood two to three times per month. She also recently used her savings to buy a van, which is used to transport people between towns in the region.

Constatina and Neli need loans of 600, and 1600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to add a public telephone to their store, and to buy more wood.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account each associate has. Both Constatina and Neli have recently used their savings to open their store and to buy a van. Their dreams are to continue moving forward, and that their children will have a better life.

loans.use: Constatina and Neli need loans of 600 and 1600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to add a public telephone to their store and to buy more wood.

loans.name: Santos Elena

texts.es:
Santos Elena, 45, studied through high school. She now has three children, two of whom still live with her. She lives in the Human Victor Raul settlement in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She raises farm animals such as ducks and chickens and fattens them for sale in the nearby Santa Rosa market. Sometimes she gets larger orders for holidays such as Mother's Day, Christmas, national holidays, etc. In addition to that, she works as a street vendor, buying carnations and roses from a wholesaler in the La Hermelinda market and selling them in other local markets, and grows pineapples and avocados on a small piece of land she inherited in the "distrito" of Poroto that she harvests approximately every three months and also sells.

Thanks to some neighbors, she joined the Mujeres del Milenium ("Women of the Millenium") community bank where she received her first loan of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$100). With the money, she bought feed for her animals. With this loan of S/.1000, to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy eight sacks of processed feed, 30 dozen roses and 30 dozen carnations. Santos Elena dream of buying a stand in the market and setting up a flower shop.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Santos Elena A. M. tiene 45 años de edad, estudió secundaria completa. Tiene tres hijos en total pero sólo dos dependen de ella. Vive en el Asentamiento Humano Víctor Raúl, distrito de El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad. Su negocio consiste en la crianza de animales menores tales como patos, pollos y gallinas, a los cuales engorda para venderlos en el mercado “Santa Rosa” ubicado en el distrito en el que vive. A veces le hacen pedidos al por mayor en fechas especiales como día de la madre, navidad, fiestas patrias, etc., además en el mercado “La Hermelinda” compra variedad de flores, claveles y rosas al por mayor para volver a vender en condición de ambulante por distintos mercados de la ciudad. En un pequeño terreno que heredó en el distrito de Poroto ha sembrado algunas plantas como piñas y paltas que cosecha cada tres meses aproximadamente, productos que también trae a vender en los mercados.

Gracias a unas vecinas ingresó al Banco Comunal “Mujeres del Milenium”, lugar donde obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300, con este dinero compró el alimento para sus animales: concentrado y maíz. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual pagará en cuatro meses, comprará ocho sacos de concentrado, 30 docenas de rosas y 30 docenas de claveles. La señora Elena sueña con comprar un puesto en el mercado e implementar una florería.

loans.use: Buy animal feed for livestock business and flowers for resale.

loans.name: Mirna Maribel

texts.en:
Mirna Maribel Garcia D. C. owns land where she raises and sells pigs in the town of Picota, San Martin. She started the business 6 months ago because she wanted her family to have a second income. Although she has no prior business experience, she has already experienced much success. She is very friendly and loves building relationships with clients.

Mirna is 33 years old, married and has 3 children. She is happy to have started her business. She now feels useful, has more friends, and greater sense of self-esteem. She is proud she can help her family and save for her children’s education.

A member of Manuela Ramos and the community bank Los Claveles, Mirna is requesting a loan of S/. 800 to be repaid over a period of 6 months. She will use her loan to purchase more piglets because there is a high demand for pork in Picota.

loans.use: To purchase piglets.

loans.name: Elza

texts.es:
Elza belongs to Banco Comunal “Niño Manuelito.” She is dedicated to the sale of food in the Río quarry where they extract construction materials. This is in the city of Huaraz in Ancash region. With a previous loan of S. 1,200.00, she invested in the business to improve her earnings. With this new loan of S. 1,500.00, which will be repaid in eight months, she will invest in the purchase of rice, noodles, oil and other products for cooking meals. She is 26 years old and is married with two children. Her husband is a worker and has temporary work. The wage that he earns is not enough to pay for their living expenses. Her earnings allow Elza to feed and clothe her family.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

La Señora Elza, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Niño Manuelito”, se dedica a la venta de alimentos en la cantera del Río donde extraen materiales de construcción. Esto en la ciudad de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash. Con el crédito anterior de S/1,200.00 nuevos soles, invirtió en negocio para mejorar sus ingresos, Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500 nuevos soles el cual será cancelado en 8 meses lo invertirá en la compra de: arroz, fideos, aceite, y otros productos para la elaboración de alimentos. Ella tiene 26 años es casada con dos hijos, su esposo es obrero y tiene trabajos eventuales y el sueldo que gana no alcanza para solventar su hogar, sus ingreso le permite vestir y alimentar a su familia.

loans.use: With this loan, she will buy basic necessities for her business.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz T. C. sells chickens in the main market of Picota in the Department of San Martin. She has been selling chickens in the stall, which she rents from the municipality of Picota, since 2005. She started the business because she wanted to help pay for her family's basic needs and save for her children’s education.

Luz is 34 years old and is happily married with 2 children. She loves her business. Although she has an advanced degree in administration from a technical school, she prefers working in the market.

A member of Manuela Ramos Credi Mujer and the community bank Mujeres En Accion, Luz is requesting a loan of S/800 to be repaid over 6 months. With this loan, Luz would like to buy more chickens and chicken feed.

loans.use: To buy chickens and chicken feed

loans.name: Glinda

texts.en:
Glinda G. M. D. Redriguez runs a juice bar in the main market of Picota, San Martin. She rents a spot in the market from the town municipality where she serves fresh juices, sandwiches and cakes daily. Glinda has run her business for ten years so she has plenty of experience and many loyal customers.

Glinda is 49 years old, married, and has four children. She loves working and feeding her community delicious meals. Her husband is supportive and they both work hard to send their children to university so their children can have more opportunities in life than they did.

A member of Manuela Ramos and the community bank Los Claveles, Glinda is requesting a loan of S/. 1,000 to invest in her business and repay in 6 months. With this loan, she would like to buy fruit and a new more powerful blender.

loans.use: To buy fruit and a new blender

loans.name: Emerita

texts.es:
Emerita C. D. V. is 56 years old and only finished primary school. She has seven children but none of them are dependent on her anymore.

She lives in the Human Victor Raúl settlement, El Porgenir district, Trujillo province, in the department of La Libertad, Perú.

Shortly before joining the Banco Communal "Women of the Millenium" she started raising animals. She began with 10 small ducks that she fed. When they were bigger some produced eggs and in this way she was able to increase her number of animals. She later bought chickens and other animals. She now sells some of the bigger ducks and chickens to wholesellers in the various markets in the city like La Victoria, Santa Rosa and Sant Inés.

With the first loan that she received in the amount of 300 soles, she bought food for her animals: including concentrates and corn.

With this loan of 1800 soles that she will repay over 4 months she will buy construction supplies to improve her house and above all the space where she raises the animals.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Emerita C. D. V. tiene 56 años D. edad, estudió sólo primaria completa. Tiene siete hijos en total pero ya ninguno depenD. D. ella.

Vive en el Asentamiento Humano Víctor Raúl en el distrito D. El Porvenir en la provincia D. Trujillo en el departamento La Libertad - Perú

Un poco antes D. ingresar al Banco Comunal “Mujeres del Milenium” empezó a criar animales, se inició con 10 patos pequeños los cuales alimentaba y conforme crecían algunos D. ellos producía huevos, D. esa manera fue incrementando la cantidad D. animales, posteriormente compró pollos y cuyes. Actualmente sacrifica algunos patos y pollos grandes y venD. a los mayoristas D. los diferentes mercados D. la ciudad como La Victoria, Santa Rosa y Santa Inés.

Con el primer préstamo que recibió D. S/. 300.00 compró alimento para sus animales: concentrado, purina y maíz.

Con el préstamo D. S/. 1800.00 el cual pagará en 4 meses comprará material D. construcción para mejorar su vivienda sobre todo el espacio donD. cría los animales.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy construction materials

loans.name: Rosa Aurora

texts.en:
Rosa Aurora P. L. runs a general store in the town of Picota, San Martin. She’s had this business for 3 years but ran a food stand at a high school for 10 years before that. She runs a smaller store in her house as well. Rosa is always friendly and provides the best service possible. Her clients are happy that they don’t need to walk across town to the main market when they need to buy everyday goods.

Rosa is 46 years old, married and has four children. She enjoys working and building relationships. She is proud of the fact that she can afford to send her children to school and provide more opportunities for them than she had.

A member of Manuela Ramos CrediMujer and the community bank Mujeres En Accion, Rosa is requesting a loan of S/ 2,000 to be repaid over 6 months. With this loan, Rosa would like to buy rice, oil, candy, soda, and beer.

loans.use: Buy rice, oil, candy, soda an beer

loans.name: Antonia Angelica's Group

texts.en:
Antonia, Teodora, and Alejandra have been members of the community bank “Ollantay II” for one, twelve, and six years respectively. They joined the community bank because there were fewer forms and requirements, they do not have to put up collateral. Through the bank they have learned about self-esteem, saving, responsibility, and healthy relationships.

Antonia is 30 years old. She is married and has four children, the youngest being nine months. Antonia sells jewelry from a stand in the market. She makes some of it and buys other pieces from Lima. She has been selling jewelry for seven years.

Teodora is 39 years old. She is also married and has four children. Teodora sells candies from a stand near the local school. She has been running this business for fifteen years.

Alejandra is 45 years old. She is married and has six children between the ages of 28 and 12. Alejandra has a store where she sells food staples such as flour, rice, and sugar. In the past she sold her products from a cart. She has been able to buy a house and now has a store located in her home.

Antonia, Teodora, and Alejandra each need loans of 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy things such as earings, necklaces, candies, gum, chocolates, rice, noodles, and milk.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Antonia, Teodora, and Alejandra plan to use their savings to make more capital available for their business, build a home, and pay for their children’s education. Their dreams are to open a store, and that their children will finish their education and have a better life.

loans.use: Antonia, Teodora, and Alejandra each need loans of 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy things such as earings, necklaces, candies, gum, chocolates, rice, noodles, and milk.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha's family includes her, her husband and three children for whom she always wants to provide the very best. They live in a rented house because her husband's earnings won't cover both a house of their own and their children's school expenses. The principal driver behind Martha's decision to start a business was her children. She discussed her worries about starting a business with her sister, a seamstress, who helped her by sending her clothes. She began by selling to friends and neighbors and, little by little, she's expanded her business.

Martha now wants more clothes so that can offer a bigger variety in her store. That's why she's asking for a US$475 loan, to be repaid in 6 months, that she can use to help her children and, in the future, have a house of their own. With your help, Martha will make her dream come true.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La familia de Martha está integrada por ella, su esposo y tres hijos a quienes desea brindarles siempre lo mejor, debido a que no cuentan con casa propia y en dónde viven están rentando, es por lo que lo que gana su esposo no es suficiente para pagar los gastos de la casa, y los de la escuela de sus hijos. El principal motor para que Martha comenzara su propio negocio fueron sus hijos. Al platicarle a su hermana la inquietud de poner un negocio, ella le ayudó enviándole ropa, ya que su hermana tiene un taller de costura, en un inicio Martha comenzó a ofrecerle ropa a sus amigos y vecinos y poco a poco ha ido incrementando su negocio.

Sin embargo Martha desea comprar más ropa para poder tener variedad en su tienda, es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Martha podrá sacar adelante a sus hijos y en un futuro poder tener una casa propia. Con tu ayuda Martha logrará hacer su sueño realidad.

loans.use: Buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Cenina

texts.es:
Cenina belongs to the Banco Comunal "Sacred Heart of Jesus." She sells small animals and grows vegetables in the small village of Llacshu, Caraz district, Huaylas province, department of Ancash.

With her previous loan of 500 soles she invested in her business to increase her income. With this loan of 300 soles, which she will repay in 4 installments, she will buy supplies for her vegetables and to feed her small animals.

Cenina is 52 years old, and is a widow with 8 children. She says that her income helps her cover her household costs.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La Señora Cenina pertenece al banco comunal “Sagrado Corazón de Jesús”. Se dedica a la venta de animales menores y a la siembra de hortalizas en el caserío de Llacshu, distrito de Caraz, provincia de Huaylas, departamento de Ancash.

Con el crédito anterior de S/. 500 invirtió en su negocio para mejorar sus ingresos. Con el préstamo de S/. 300, el cual pagará en 4 cuotas, comprará insumos para sus hortalizas y alimento para sus animales menores.

Cenina tiene 52 años de edad, es viuda con 8 hijos. Menciona que sus ingresos le permite solventar sus gastos del hogar.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies such as food for her animals and fertilizer for her vegetables

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
A while ago, Virginia worked in a restaurant as a cook. Nevertheless, after she lost her job, she decided to talk to her husband and explain her desire to sell products since Virginia believed that she had a knack for selling. She began in March 2004 selling produce and shellfish sauces and, in this way, complemented the work of her husband who is a purchaser/seller of fish and shellfish. Virginia would offer produce and sauces for the preparation of the fish and shellfish. Since then, she has dedicated herself to this task. Little by litte, she has grown her business.

Nevertheless, currently, she does not have sufficient merchandise for this Easter season when the sale of fish increases in her area. As a result, she is requesting a loan of US $475 which she will repay in four months. With your help, Virginia will be able to get ahead and help her three children to study at university.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

Desde hace tiempo Virginia trabajaba en un restaurant como cocinera, sin embargo después de que se quedó sin empleo, decidió hablar con su esposo para explicarle las ganas que tenía de vender artículos, puesto que Virginia considera que tiene habilidades para las ventas. Comenzó en el mes de Marzo de 2004, con la venta de verduras y las salsas para mariscos, ya que de esta manera se complementaría con la actividad de su esposo, que es la compra-venta de pescados y mariscos, y Virginia ofrecería las verduras y las salsas para prepararlas y desde entonces se dedica a esta actividad. Y poco a poco ha ido creciendo su negocio.

Sin embargo actualmente no cuenta con suficiente mercancía para esta temporada de pascua que es cuando se incrementa la venta de pescados en su localidad, es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 4 meses, con tu ayuda Virginia podrá salir adelante y ayudar a sus tres hijos a estudiar una carrera universitaria.

loans.use: Purchase material.

loans.name: Maybe Liz

texts.es:
Mrs. Maybe Liz L. Ramírez belongs to Grupo Mientras Tanto Yungay Hermosura. Her business is located in the town and province of Yungay, in the Ancash region. Her determination and spirit of working so that she can get ahead has allowed her to contribute towards the costs of her family. Her business is in a rented shop started with a previous loan of S. 300.00. She has grown her business and her earnings. With this loan of S. 500.00, repaid in four months, she will invest in the purchase of more basic necessities for cooking like rice, sugar, noodles, oil, and salt. Maybe Liz serves pensioners and customers who come to eat daily. She is 26 years old, has one five-year-old child and her husband has temporary work. With her earnings, she will support her husband and child and her goal is to continue to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

La Señora Maybe Liz L. Ramírez, pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto Yungay Hermosura su negocio esta ubicado en la localidad de Yungay, provincia de Yungay, departamento de Ancash, su empeño y espíritu de trabajar para poder salir adelante le ha permitido aportar en los gastos de su familia, su negocio esta en un local alquilado es lo Con el crédito anterior de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, ha incrementado su negocio y sus ingresos. Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en la compra de mas insumos de primera necesidad para la elaboración de alimentos, arroz, azúcar, fideos, aceite, sal, la señora cuenta pensionistas y clientes que van a consumir diariamente Ella tiene 26 años, tiene un hijo de 5 años y su esposo tiene trabajo eventual, con los ingresos que tiene apoya a su hijo y esposo, su meta es seguir creciendo con su negocio.

loans.use: With a loan, she will buy basic ecessities for her restaurant.

loans.name: Kireka B1 A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose Mary N.. She is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to boost business. Rose is 28 years old and is married to a husband who is a civil servant for work. She has 2 children of ages 7 and 9 and her children go to school. Each week, Rose makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house. Rose has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 1000000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Rose is joined in her small group by Joweria N., Agnes K., Angelina Nagulo, and Zulaika K.. Joweria N. has a business running a canteen and wants to add capital. Agnes K. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to increase her stock of shop items. Angelina Nagulo operates a business of vegetable selling and wants to boost business. Zulaika K. is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase a hair dryer.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Kireka B1 B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Christine M.. She is currently in the business of poultry keeping and is requesting a loan to purchase poultry feed. Christine is 36 years old and is married. Her husband is a tailor. She has 2 children of ages 16 and 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Christine makes approximately UGX 135000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a piece of land. Christine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Christine is joined in her small group by Rose M., Hasifah N., Teddy N., and Aisha K.. Rose M. has a business in charcoal selling and wants to expand to bulk selling. Hasifah N. is currently operating a business in charcoal sales and wants a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Teddy N. operates a restaurant business and wants to buy more furniture. Aisha K. is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase hair oils and chemicals.

loans.use: To add in poultry business

loans.name: Kireka B1 C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Joweria N.. She is currently in the business of selling rice and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of rice. Joweria is 33 years old and is married. Her husband is a civil servant. She has 6 children ranging from age 9 to18 and her children go to school. Each week, Joweria makes approximately UGX 230000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build houses to rent. Joweria has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Joweria is joined in her small group by Sarah L., Harriet N., Alice N., and Madina N.. Sarah L. has a business running a canteen and wants to add to her business. Harriet N. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to increase stock. Alice N. operates a business of matooke selling and wants to increase her inventory. Madina N. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase food warmers.

loans.use: To boost and expand rice business

loans.name: Kireka B7 A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ruth M.. She is currently in the business of running a canteen and is requesting a loan to increase stock. Ruth is 48 years old and is a widow. She has 9 children ranging from age 20 to 34. Two of her children go to school while others work. Each week, Ruth makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up other businesses. Ruth has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Ruth is joined in her small group by Milly N., Slyvia N., Teopista K., and Resty N.. Milly N. has a restaurant business and wants to buy more food, cutlery and utensils. Slyvia N. is currently operating a bar business and wants a loan to purchase more crates of beer and furniture. Teopista K. operates a business of shoe sales and wants to increase inventory. Resty N. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan to add more working capital.

loans.use: To add to canteen business

loans.name: Kireka B1 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Margret N.. She is currently in the business of selling arts and crafts and is requesting a loan to boost business. Margret is 48 years old and is a widow. She has 1 child who is 30. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it for future use. Margret has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Margret is joined in her small group by Hadijah M., Slyvia N., Maureen K., and Annet N.. Hadijah M. has a business running a restaurant and wants to purchase more raw food. Slyvia N. is currently operating a business in stone quarrying and wants a loan to add capital. Maureen K. operates a restaurant business and wants to purchase a fridge. Annet N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan to expand business.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for making arts and crafts

loans.name: Kireka B7 B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hamidah N.. She is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Hamidah is 48 years old and is married. Her husband is a builder. She has 7 children ranging from age 10 to 29 and her children go to school. Each week, Hamidah makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save it for her children's school fees. Hamidah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Hamidah is joined in her small group by Rebecca N., Jane N., Justine N., and Kawala J.. Rebecca N. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to increase stock and construct a charcoal shade/store. Jane N. is currently operating a business in poultry farming and wants a loan to buy chicken feed. Justine N. operates a restaurant business and wants to invest and improve her business. Kawala J. is currently in the business of selling vegetables and is requesting a loan to add to the business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell and also put up a boutique

loans.name: Eka Sukartini

texts.en: Eka, 34, is a mother of 4 children; 3 boys and 1 girl. Her husband, S., has no fixed job so he could not provide enough income for the family. To help her husband cover the family needs she sells clothings on credit door-to-door. She collects the payment weekly, earning $10 a week. She is a member of MBK and is now asking for a loan of $75 to add to her business capital. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her business capital
